texts.en: Saddam, 20 years old and single, lives in the Philippines where he has had a shop that sells t-shirts, blouses, shoes and sandals for four years. A  member of HSPFI since 2009, he is requesting a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy stocks of clothing and shoes.  In the future, Saddam hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy stocks of clothing and shoes.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en: Rosita, a 70-year-old married mother of nine, lives in the Philippines where she has had a coffee shop that sells and serves breads and a variety of beverages for 10 years. A member of HSPFI, Rosita is requesting a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy more coffee and breads, and in the future hopes to improve her enterprise.

loans.use: to buy coffee and breads for her shop.

loans.name: Lea

texts.en: Lea, a 48-year-old married woman with four children ranging in age from 26 to 13 years, is a farmer who primarily grows rice crops to sell. She also bakes bread for sale to the people in her community.  Lea has requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes to buy a carabao (domesticated water buffalo) in the future.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Darma Sedana Group

texts.en: Like many Balinese women, Ni Ketut and the other members of the Darma Sedana group raise pigs in their yards to supplement their families’ incomes.  Though many women support their families in this way, they may not know the best way to raise pigs to maximize income. Ni Ketut  hopes that, through the MUK Pig Breeder Loan program, she will not only recieve capital but also training from MUK on the best way to feed and care for pigs. Ni Ketut will use her share of the loan to purchase two piglets and pig feed. She plans to sell the piglets after six months for use as fattening pigs. With her profits, she will help support her family of four by supplementing her husband's income from his work as a day laborer. Ultimately, Ni Ketut hopes that increased income will enable her to renovate her simple kitchen.

loans.use: to purchase two piglets and pig feed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a metal-cutting machine for her husband.

loans.name: Mey

texts.en:
Mr. Mey, 47, is the head of family, and lives in Dongkor Commune of Phnom Penh. Being responsible for a big family, he always decides how to earn more money in his family. He and his wife are interested in making a business as a chicken meat seller in one of the markets near the house. 

In helping the family in improvement, his wife works as hard as her husband everyday. As they both work harder, they can earn $6 per day. Additionally, they have four children, two of whom are working as sewing factory workers and another one is working as a garment factory worker in Phnom Penh.

He is asking for a loan to purchase a lot of chickens for selling.  He wishes to enlarge his current house, and to support his kids to finish their highest degrees.

loans.use: to purchase a lot of chickens for selling

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca, a married mother of three children, all of whom are in school, lives in Uganda where she has an enterprise selling half-bricks. In business for 10 years and working 6 days each week, Rebecca sells her products wholesale from home. Her main business challenges are transportation and seasonality. She has requested a loan of 500000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more half-bricks. Her main business goal is to acquire a delivery van to facilitate transportation.

Rebecca lives in a home that she owns; she has access to neither electricity nor piped water. Her major monthly expenses include medication, school fees and food for the family.

loans.use: to buy more half-bricks.

loans.name: Marito

texts.en: Marito is 58 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with 2 children. Marito is providing pedicab services. He has had this business for 5 years. He requested a loan for 7,000 PHP to buy tools for the pedicab. Marito has been a member of HSPFI since 2006. In the future, Marito hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy tools for the pedicab

loans.name: Norman

texts.en: Norman is 48 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with 2 children. Norman has a shop that sells snacks and vegetables like string beans and eggplants. He has had this business for 4 years. He requested a loan for 7,000 PHP to buy snacks and vegetables to sell. Norman has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Norman hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy snacks and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for taxi maintenance expenses.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en: Milagros is 55 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 6 children. Milagros has a shop that sells green bananas and coconuts for copras. She has had this business for 6 years. She requested a loan for 6,000 PHP to buy bananas and coconuts to sell. Milagros has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Milagros hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy bananas and coconuts to sell

loans.name: Altantuul

texts.en:
Altantuul is a 40-year-old divorced woman who lives with her three daughters in a rented apartment in the Sansar area of Ulaanbaatar city.  Her youngest daughter, who is 11 years old, attends secondary school. 

Altantuul manages a Mongolian traditional shoe-making business with the help of her daughters. She started her business in 2000 and is planning to expand it in the future. All of her children make a variety of shoes for all ages and Altantuul herself is responsible for selling the goods. They produce and manufacture the shoes in their home. 

Altantuul sells her goods at a rented stall at Narantuul market, one of the busiest markets in Mongolia. She is a diligent and honest woman who is planning to purchase large amount of materials for her business in order to make a collection of shoes before Naadam, Mongolia's biggest national holiday. She says, "I am one of the trusted loan recipients of XacBank, and I am happy to have a long-term relationship with XacBank." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her shoe-making business.

loans.name: Concordia

texts.en:
Concordia is 50 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 1 child.

Concordia has a shop that sells green and yellow bananas, and coconuts. She has had this business for 6 years. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy bananas and coconuts to sell.  Concordia has been a member of HSPFI since 2008. In the future, Concordia hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy bananas and coconuts to sell

loans.name: Say

texts.en:
In a simple living standard, Mrs. Say, 36, has been living in Prey Chor district, Kompong Cham Province. She has given birth to five children. Every night, Mrs. Say always thinks with her husband on how to earn more money for their family. After she was married, the parents of Mrs. Say contributed land for her. She has decided to make a farm with her husband now. When she and her husband do farm, they could be earning approximately $5 per day. 

To help the family, one of the five children is working as a sewing factor worker in Phnom Penh, which provides a suitable salary per month. To improve their living standard, they are requesting a loan in the amount of $250 to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farming materials.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farming materials.

loans.name: Merilyn

texts.en:
Merilyn is 50 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children.
 
Merilyn has a shop that sells green and yellow bananas. She has had this business for 5 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy green bananas to sell. Merilyn has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Merilyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy green bananas to sell

loans.name: Parvina

texts.ru: Парвина проживает в городе Душанбе. Ей 33 года. Она замужем. У нее один ребенок. Она имеет высшее образование, финансист. По профессии работает 5 месяцев. Кроме того она занимается шитьем национальных платьев у себя дома. Этим видом деятельности она занимается три года. Кредит берет для покупки материалов. Она хочет сшить платья для продажи.
texts.en: Parvina lives in the city of Dushanbe.  She is 33 years old, married and has one child.  She has a higher education as a financial advisor.  She has been working in her field for five months.  Besides this work, she is also involved in sewing national dresses at her home.  Parvina has been in this business for three years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of materials.  She wants to make dresses for sale.

loans.use: to purchase sewing materials

loans.name: Bernaflor

texts.en:
Bernaflor is 23 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children. 

Bernaflor has a shop that sells bananas and coconuts. She has had this business for 3 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy bananas and coconuts. Bernaflor has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Bernaflor hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy bananas and coconuts

loans.name: Shida

texts.en:
Shida is a married man with five children, three boys and two girls. He lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and school fees.

For the past two years, he has operated a café business, selling cooked food such as beans, rice and chapati (flat bread) to his neighbors and passersby. He faces a major challenge of competition from other café operators in the future.

With the KES 20,000 loan, he wants to purchase furniture for his café business, chairs and tables. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase chairs and tables for his café

loans.name: Bayarmagnai

texts.en:
Bayarmagnai is 53 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in the Sansar area of Ulaanbaatar city. His older son, age 24, helps with the family business while his younger son, age 19, works as a welder. 

Bayarmagnai manages a shoe-making business with the help of his wife. He started his business in 2000 and gained much experience. He learned how to make shoes on his own, and then taught his older son. Now he rents a stall with a monthly payment of 40,000 MNT.  Bayarmagnai's working capital has reached 1,500,000 MNT, with daily earnings of 50,000-100,000 MNT. 

He is a polite man who wants to renew his old equipment in order to expand his business. He says, "I'll have the advantage to conduct my business successfully if I can renew my equipment." He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase equipment and some materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase equipment and some materials

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a married man with two school-going children.  The family lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for his children. 

David has operated a poultry business for the past two years, selling from home to his neighbors and restaurant operators. He faces a major challenge of competition and disease outbreak in his poultry business. He dreams of owning his own plot in the future.

With the KES 40,000 loan, he wants to purchase more chicks and chicken feed. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase more chicks and chicken feed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Oyundelger

texts.en:
Oyundelger is 51 years old and lives with her husband and two children in an apartment in the Sansar area of Ulaanbaatar city. Her husband is a plumber who owns his business. Her older son is a programmer in a private company while her younger one is a student. 

Oyundelger manages a handicraft-making business which started this year.  Before that, she worked as a dressmaker for private companies. Now she rents a stall where she sells her goods. Her business is operating quite successfully which allowed her to employ 3 more workers. She is planning to expand her business and wants to make a greater variety of goods in the future. She is a responsible and kind woman who is doing her best in order to manage both her business and private life properly. 

She says, "I am having more freedom by running my own business. I love doing it."  Oyundelger is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase materials

loans.name: Munkhjargal

texts.en:
Munkhjargal, 41, is a home television repairman.  He lives with his wife and 4 children in his own house in Erdenet, the third-largest city in Mongolia. His older daughter, 21, works for a private company. The others are pupils in secondary school. 

Munkhjargal started his own business in 2000 and he plans to expand and improve it in the future. Currently, he and his family are renovating their home to improve their living conditions. But now he can’t finish the renovation, due to a finance issue. Therefore, Munkhjargal is taking a loan to buy some construction materials to finish the adjustment to his house and improve the family's quality of life.

loans.use: To buy some construction materials to finish a home renovation

loans.name: Jalia

texts.en:
Jalia lives in Uganda.  She is married and has six children, four of whom are in school. Jalia has a business of selling second hand shoes. She has been in this business for five years, and she works seven days out of every week.  Jalia sells her products retail at the market. 

Jalia has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second hand shoes.The main business challenges for Jalia include the ever-increasing prices of shoes as well as seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start importing shoes herself and also to sell on a wholesale basis only.

Jalia lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include medication, school fees, and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand shoes

loans.name: Samira

texts.en:
Samira is a 53-year-old woman, who is married to Ali who is photographed in his ice cream shop. Samira has two daughters and two sons, and she lives in Gaza city in Palestine. Her two sons are Palestinian National Authority employees. 

 Samira's husband sells ice cream in his grocery shop. He wants to add an ice cream making machine in addition to the ice cream he sells. Samira took out a loan from FATEN to give her husband the chance to purchase it and attract more customers.

Samira is a conservative woman.

loans.use: to purchase an ice cream making machine.

loans.name: Damalie

texts.en:
Damalie lives in Uganda. She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. Damalie has a business of selling used clothes  She has been in this business for four years, and she works six days out of every week. Damalie sells her products in a shop, by means of retail trade. 

Damalie has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of clothes. She also generates additional income through poultry farming. The main business challenges for Damalie include defaulters and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start importing clothes and also to sell on a wholesale basis only. 

Damalie lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, medication, school fees, and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bales of clothes

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, she has operated a business of supplying sand and building materials. She supplies sand to contractors and constructors of houses using her lorry. Hellen faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation and seasonality. She dreams of establishing a sand depot to sell as wholesale and establish a boutique shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of sand, and spare parts to service her lorry. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of sand, and spare parts to service her lorry.

loans.name: Annabel

texts.en:
Annabel is 30 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Annabel has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks and detergents. She has had this business for six years. She requested a loan of 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Annabel has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Annabel hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
For the past four years, Sofia has operated a poultry farming business, selling from door to door and from home to her neighbors. She faces the major challenges of seasonality, especially during the rainy season when it becomes difficult to operate a poultry business, and competition from other poultry operators. Sofia dreams of establishing a boutique business in the future.
With her loan of 40,000 KES, Sofia wants to purchase one-day-old chicks and chicken feed. She decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase one-day-old chicks and chicken feed.

loans.name: Pich

texts.en:
Mrs. Pich, 30, married a few years ago and is raising two children. To try to earn a living, Mrs. Pich works as a fish seller in a market near her house. To help support their family, her husband doesn’t stay at home. He  is employed as a local factory worker which gets him a suitable salary to give his wife every month. Mrs. Pich and her husband can earn $8 per day. 

Since her business is improving. Mrs. Pich wishes to ask for a loan in the amount of $1,000  to purchase more fish to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell at the market.

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita is 51 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed with six children.
Estelita has a shop that sells vegetables such as eggplants. She has run this business for 16 years. She has requested a loan for 5,000 PHP to buy vegetables to sell. Estelita has been a member of Kiva partner, HSPFI, since 2010. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Nike Group

texts.en:
Mohamed, who is in his early 30s, is single. He has been a tailor for three years now. He works from 8a.m to 8p.m. daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.
This will be Mohamed's sixth loan from Kiva partner, Tujijenje Tanzania. He used his previous loans to buy materials and sewing equipment such as threads, needles, lining and ribbons and has paid back all his loans successfully. He is requesting a loan to buy materials, threads, needles, lining and ribbons for his tailoring business. His dream is to one day buy a plot of land.
Mohamed will share this loan with his loan group "Nike," which has a total of 19 members. All the members will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy materials, threads, needles, lining and ribbons for his tailoring business.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
For the past five years, Esther has operated a clothes sales business, selling from home to her neighbors and passers-by. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. Her major goal is to establish a sales stall for her business. With her loan of 20,000 KES, Esther wants to purchase bundles of clothes for resale. She decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Normelita

texts.en:
Normelita is 44 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with seven children.
Normelita has a shop that sells vegetables and bananas. She has run this business for five years. She has requested a loan for 5,000 PHP to buy vegetables to sell. Normelita has been a member of Kiva partner, HSPFI, since 2008. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth lives in Uganda. She is married and has six children, four of whom are in school. Ruth lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, medication, school fees and food for the family.
Ruth has a business selling women's handbags. She has been in this business for ten years, and she works seven days a week. Ruth sells her products in a shop, by means of retail. She has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy to buy more bales of bags. She also generates additional income through selling clothes and jeans. The main business challenges for Ruth include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start importing bags herself and also to sell wholesale only.

loans.use: to buy more second-hand women's handbags.

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Olivia lives in Uganda. She is married and has four children, none of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (one orphan of her late sister). Olivia lives in a home that she rents; she doesn't have access to electricity or piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, medication, school fees for the orphan and food for the family.
Olivia has a business selling second-hand clothes (bras). She has been in this business for ten years, and works six days a week. Olivia sells her products door to door, by means of retail. Olivia has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second-hand clothes (bras). The main business challenges for Olivia include transportation and the rainy season, which hinders her movements. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to find permanent business premises and also to sell wholesale only.

loans.use: to buy more bales of second-hand clothes (bras).

loans.name: Kibondo Group

texts.en:
Vedasto, who is in his mid 30s, is married with two children, one of whom goes to school. He has been selling second-hand clothes since 1997. He works from 9a.m to 10p.m. daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.
This will be Vedasto's first loan from Kiva partner, Tujijenge Tanzania, which he wants to use for buying more second-hand clothes to sell. His dream is to be able to finish his house one day. He will share this loan with his loan group "Kibondo," which has a total of 17 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy more second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence lives in Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. Florence lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but no piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and food for the family.
Florence has a food stall business. She has been in this business for five years, and she works six days a week. Florence sells her products at the market, by means of wholesale/retail. Florence has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy to buy more baskets of tomatoes and onions. Florence earns additional income through hiring out her bicycle. The main business challenges for Florence include perishability and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy directly from farmers and also to start growing tomatoes herself.

loans.use: to buy more baskets of tomatoes and onions.

loans.name: Sifa

texts.en:
Sifa is a married man with two children, both of whom attend school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
For the past five years, Sifa has operated a boda boda (motorcycle) business. His potential customers are neighbors and passers-by. He faces the major challenge of competition from other motorcycle businesses. Sifa dreams of establishing a motorcycle spare parts shop in the future.
With his loan of 10,000 KES, Sifa wants to purchase spare parts to repair his motorcycle. He decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts to repair his motorcycle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for preparing a space to exhibit furniture in her husband's workshop

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy lives in Uganda. She is married and has seven children, all of whom are in school. Teddy lives in a home that she owns; she doesn't have access to electricity or piped water. Her major monthly expenses include medication, school fees and food for the family.
Teddy has a bakery business. She has run this business for ten years, and she works six days a week. Teddy sells her products at the market, by means of retail. She has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more cartons of baking flour and cooking oil. The main business challenges for Teddy include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a delivery van to ease transportation problems and also to see her business grow into a big bakery.

loans.use: to buy cartons of baking flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Aishabubu's Group

texts.en:
Aishabubu, 66, is the leader of this group.  She is the resident of Tokmok, a small town near to Bishkek (capital of Kyrgyzstan). Unfortunately she is a widow. All her daughters have grown up and have their own families. Fifteen years ago, In order earn money,  Aishabubu  started to provide sewing services. She sews Kyrgyz national clothes, pillows and blankets. With the profits gained from this activity Aishabubu was able to give a good education to her daughters. She has applied for the loan because she needs additional financial funds to purchase a multifunctional sewing machine. She hopes it will help her to improve the business. In the future, with the profits gained, Aishabubu plans to repair her house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, Mwanatumu has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With a Kshs 20,000 loan Mwanatumu wants to purchase cereals, sacks of beans, maize, rice and maize flour.  She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Her major dream is to expand her business in the future.

.

loans.use: To purchase cereals, sacks of beans, maize, rice and maize flour.

loans.name: Batdulam

texts.en: Batdulam is  a 28 year old hard-working single woman who lives in her brother’s apartment in Darkhan, the second largest city in Mongolia. She runs a  business selling brand cosmetics in a shopping center.  Recently, she had a car accident and spent a lot of money on her medication. Her business was stopped for 5 months and it has not been working well since she came back from her accident. Batdulam is now planning  to reconstruct and expand  her  business.  She has had  some experience with loans and knows how to use her loan and how to repay it efficiently. The loan Batdulam is taking will be dedicated to reorganizing and expanding her cosmetics business.

loans.use: To reconstruct and expand her commercial business.

loans.name: Julian

texts.en: Julian  lives in  Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children, all of whom are in school.  Julian also  has a pub business in her home.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days a week. Julian has requested a loan of 600000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more crates of beer and soda, boxes of mineral water and jerrycans of local gin. The main business challenge(s) for Julian include defaulters and the rainy season which hinders her customer’s movements.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked pub and also to sell wholesale only. Julian lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, medication, school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer, soda and jerrycans of local gin

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is 56 years old and married to Jacob. Her husband runs a posho mill business in order to get additional income for the family. Their children are ages eighteen,sixteen,fourteen,twelve,and ten years. Flora is a farmer. Her monthly income from the business is KES.15,000.

Flora is asking for  a loan of KES.20,000 to buy seeds and fertilizer. She plans to use the anticipated profits to pay school fees and to plow her land next year. Flora successfully repaid her previous loan. She hopes to expand her farming and to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao, pictured here with her husband, is 41 years old and married with two children. Since 1979, she has been living in the Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham Province. Sao and her husband are farmers who work and care for their farm every day to honorably support their family. Together, they earn 4 USD daily. 

Sao is requesting a loan of 125 USD to purchase fertilizer, seed, and other materials to improve her farming business. In the future, she and her husband would like to buy a new plowing machine and hope that their children are able to finish high school.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, seed, and farm inputs

loans.name: Lukiya

texts.en:
Lukiya lives in Uganda. She is married and has five children, three of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren).   

Lukiya has a business of selling second-hand clothes. She has been in this business for five years and she works six days out of every week. Lukiya sells her products door-to-door, by means of wholesale/retail. 

Lukiya has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. Lukiya gets additional income through bricklaying work.    

The main business challenges for Lukiya include the ever increasing prices of clothes and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to get a permanent place for her business and also to sell on a wholesale basis only. 

Lukiya lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include medication,   school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Majeda

texts.en:
Majeda is a 45-year-old woman who is married and has three sons and two daughters. Majeda's husband Abdul Salam is a taxi driver who drives passengers inside and outside the city. His income is not enough to cover licensing and insurance fees, therefore Majeda took out a loan from FATEN to pay for them. 

Majeda is a conservative woman, therefore her husband is photographed instead.

loans.use: To pay for car licencing and insurance

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a single woman with one child who attends school. She owns a house that has electricity and running water and her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. For the past three years, Esther has operated a food stall and she sells food from her home to neighbors and passersby. Her major business challenge is seasonality as during the hot dry season the availability of food is less. 

Esther decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, and cooking oil. In the future, Esther dreams of expanding her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, and cooking oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a single woman who lives in a rented house that has electricity and running water. For the past two years, she has operated both a cosmetic shop and a general retail store. Her customers are her neighbors and passersby. Betty’s major business challenge is seasonality and her greatest monthly expense is the high cost of chemicals and weaves. 

Betty is requesting a loan of 60,000 KES to purchase cosmetics for her shop and maize flour, wheat flour, and cooking oil for her general store. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. Her dream for the future is to establish another business selling charcoal.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics for her shop and maize flour, wheat flour, and cooking oil for her general store

loans.name: Battulga

texts.en:
Battulga is 45 years old and lives with his wife in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The couple has a 19-year-old daughter who lives independently. Currently, Battulga has three jobs: he is a watchman at a gasoline station; he runs a taxi business with his old car; and, since 2002, he has worked as a construction team leader at night. 

Battulga has wanted to renovate his old taxi for a long time. However, there is an issue with his car payments and he is therefore requesting a loan to repair his car. Battulga will repay his loan with the income from his two part-time jobs.

loans.use: to repair his old taxi

loans.name: Momela Group

texts.en:
Justine, who is in his early twenties, is married with one baby girl. For the past five years, he has been running a general store where he sells charcoal, fruits, and vegetables. Justine works from six in the morning through ten at night and is able to make a fair monthly profit. He will share this loan with his loan group “Momela,” which has 15 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

Justine is requesting his sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He will use this loan to increase his store’s inventory of charcoal, fruit, and vegetables. Justine used his previous loans to start his business and to provide for household and medical expenses. He has successfully repaid all of his previous loans. Justine's dream is to buy land one day.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal, fruit, and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda is a single woman who lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is rent for her house.

For the past seven years, she has owned a preparatory school, teaching children from community. She faces a major challenge in her business when parents of students she teaches delay paying school fees. She dreams of expanding her school and equipping it with enough teaching materials to incorporate upper classes in the future.

With the 80,000 Kenyan shillings from this loan, Linda wants to purchase sand and cement to renovate her school, and buy stationery. She decided to join Kiva field partner Yehu in order to access loans with the hope of boosting her business.

loans.use: to purchase sand and cement to renovate her school, and stationery

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia is a married woman with one child who attends school. She lives in a house she rents that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a cosmetics shop, selling to her neighbors and passersby. One major challenge to Sylvia in her business is competition from other cosmetics shops. She dreams of expanding her business to a wholesale shop in the future. 

With the 80,000 Kenyan shillings from this loan, she wants to purchase a photocopier machine so she can add photocopying as a service she offers to customers. She decided to join KIva field partner Yehu to access loans with the hopes of being able to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a photocopier machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizer, a posho mill, and pay for school fees

loans.name: Elizabeth Masaga

texts.en:
Elizabeth Masaga is 46 years old married to a man named John.  They have four children who are in school and they live in the Kegonga area.

Elizabeth has a small retail stand that she has been running for the past 11 years. She is applying for her fourth loan from Kiva partner KADET, after repaying her previous loans successfully. Elizabeth wants to buy more bar soap, cooking oil, salt, and sugar to add to her inventory.  She will use any profit she makes for her family's upkeep and to paying for her children's school fees.  Her desire is to be able to open her own shop soon.

loans.use: to buy soap, sugar, salt, and cooking oil

loans.name: Nay

texts.en:
Mrs. Nay, 55, is living in the Prey Chor district of Kampong Cham Province. She and her husband have been married for a long time. Both of them are farmers. They have five children, only one of whom is married. 

Seeing the good season this year, Mrs. Nay would like to borrow some funds to help her family. She asks for $75 to purchase seed and fertilizer. In the future, she hopes that she will be able to purchase a new plowing machine, repair her house, and most of all give all her children a high level of education. She appears in the photo with her husband.

loans.use: To purchase seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Evelyne

texts.en:
Evelyne is 38 years old, married, and has four children aged 6 to 22 years old. For a year she has owned a small shop where she sells groceries. Her shop is located in a residential area where she sells things to people in her community. Evelyne plans to use the proceeds of this loan to restock her store by buying more groceries. 

This is Evelyne’s first loan with Kiva field partner SMEP.  She plans to use any profit she makes from her business to open more shops in other locations. She hopes to be able to run a wholesale business in the future. Evelyne describes herself as strategically minded.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to resell at a small store

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman with four children; two are still attend school while the other two have already graduated. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past four years, she has operated a vegetable selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality, especially during rainy seasons. She dreams of expanding her business in the future. 

With the 15,000 Kenyan Shilling (KES) loan she wants to purchase bundles of vegetables for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Serfina

texts.en:
Serfina is married and has three children aged four to fifteen. She has been selling fish for the last five years and employs four people. Serfina finds that the high price of fish, caused by inflation, is pushing people to eat other types of meats. This is a challenge she faces with her business. 

Serfina plans to use her loan to stock more fish. This is her second loan with SMEP. She is a good client who pays her loan well. 

Serfina hopes to use the profits from her business to expand it by supplying fish to different parts of the community. She also hopes to sell fish directly to restaurants. Serfina describes herself as outspoken and social.

loans.use: to stock more fish for her business

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 21 years old, single, and does not support anybody else. He practices farming and has been in business for two years; his monthly income is 14,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES). He is borrowing 20,000 KES to purchase fertilizer. 

He plans to plow the land with the anticipated income from the business. This is his second loan; he successfully paid his previous loan. His dream is to continue with farming and start a family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married and has three children ranging in age from one to twelve. She is a greengrocer selling groceries in a busy market. Rose has been running this business for seven years. She plans to use this loan to buy more stock and expand her business. 

This is Rose's second loan with SMEP. She is a good client that pays back her loan well. In the future, Rose hopes to supply big stores.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her grocery business

loans.name: Uba

texts.en:
Uba is a married woman with five children, one of whom still attends school while the other four have graduated. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past ten years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Her major dream is to expand her business and live a better life in the future. 

With the 35,000 Kenyan Shilling (KES) loan she wants to purchase cereals, sacks of beans, rice and bundles of wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase cereals, sacks of beans, rice, and bundles of wheat flour.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is a 37-year-old single mother with an 11-year-old son. She runs a small retail shop along a very busy street selling various things. She has been running this business for six years and employs one person. Besides the retail shop, Cecilia also runs bureau services business. She plans to use her loan to buy flour, rice, sugar, cooking oil, beverages, detergents and others to grow her business.  

This is Cecilia’s fourth loan with SMEP. She is a good client who pays back her loan well. In the future, Cecilia hopes to own wholesale shop. She describes herself as hardworking and committed.

loans.use: flour, rice, sugar, cooking oil, beverages, detergents etc

loans.name: Enkhbaatar

texts.en:
Mr. Enkhbaatar, age 21, is a young man who is trying to build his own new family life. He lives with his wife, age 20, and daughter, age six, in his father-in-law’s house. He has been running a taxi business for two years. This year, his daughter will enter secondary school.

Recently, he had an accident when he was running his taxi business and his car is too damaged to use. But the taxi business was the main living source in their life. So his car needs to be fixed fully and then he needs to continue his business. Enkhbaatar is taking a loan to repair his broken car.

loans.use: To repair his broken car.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman with one child who has graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. Her major dream is to establish a clothes-selling shop in the future.

With the KSHS 40,000, she wants to purchase sand, blocks and cement to renovate her house. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sand, blocks and cement to renovagte her house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase plumbing materials, pipes, taps and an electric meter

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is married and has two children, ages two and five. For the past three years, she has run a tailoring shop in a residential area where she sells her services wholesale and to individuals. Asha describes herself as open-minded.

Asha is requesting a loan to expand and open another tailoring shop. This will be Asha’s first loan with SMEP. She plans to use the profits from her loan to keep expanding her business by purchasing clothing material to sell.

loans.use: to open another tailoring shop

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is 44 years old and married to Stanley Kipsang. Her children are 11, 13, 15, 17, 19, and 21 years old. For the past 23 years, Gladys has been a farmer and she works with her husband to support their family. Her monthly income is 6,000 KES.

Gladys is requesting a 20,000 KES loan to buy seeds and fertilizer. This will be her second loan and she has successfully repaid her previous one. Gladys plans to use the profit from her loan to pay school fees for her children. In the future, she hopes to continue farming and educate her children.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Tuon

texts.en:
Mrs Tuon is 35 and is married with 3 children. Her husband works as a farmer.

Mrs. Tuon is a farmer in Kampong Cham Province.  Mrs. Tuon grows rice and vegetables and has been doing it for many years.  She earns $2 per day for her work.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizer, insecticides, and to pay for plowing cost.  In the future, Mrs. Tuon hopes to send all her children to study to become a teacher and a motorbike repairer.  She is pictured with her husband.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, insecticides and to pay for plowing costs.

loans.name: Ailaine

texts.en:
Ailaine is a 37-year-old married woman with three children, ages five, 10 and 13. For the past 10 years, she has been a rice farmer in Banga, South Cotabato. Ailaine earns about 10,000 PHP every month. 

Ailaine is requesting a loan to purchase rice seed and fertilizer. In the future, she hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s house.

loans.use: to purchase rice seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en:
Damaris is 32 years old and married with four children between the ages of four and 12. He runs a small business in the Mwingi area where he sells maize, beans, green grains, and wheat flour to restaurant owners and area residents. Damaris has been running this business for 14 years. He describes himself as social and determined.

Damaris is requesting a loan to purchase maize, beans, and wheat flour. He has taken out a previous loan from SMEP and is a good client who repaid his loan on time. Damaris plans to use the profit from his business to educate his children through university. In the future, he hopes to own a vehicle, such as a lorry, to supply goods to customers outside of the Mwingi area.

loans.use: to purchase maize, beans, and wheat flour

loans.name: Fawzeya

texts.en:
Fawzeya is a 46-year-old woman; she is married and has four sons and two daughters. Two of her sons are employed: one of them is a teacher the other is a Palestinian National Authority employee. Her husband is a taxi driver whose taxi needs to be repaired and have its license renewed. The taxi's income is not enough to pay for these things, therefore Fawzeya took out a loan of $1,500 from FATEN that is to be repaid on a monthly basis. 

Fawzeya is a religious woman, therefore her son is photographed instead.

loans.use: To pay for taxi repair and licensing fees

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah is a married man with three children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and transport expenses. 

Elijah has operated a retail shop for the past six years, selling to his neighbors and passersby. He faces the major challenge of the high cost of transportation in his business. He dreams of establishing a wholesale business in the future.

With the KSHS 40,000, he wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizer for wheat and maize

loans.name: Manal

texts.en:
Manal is a 32-year-old mother who has four children. She is married to Maher, a 44-year-old man who has five children from his previous marriage. In order to help support their family, Manal started a business with her husband selling scrap items. Maher collects them, brings them back to their back yard, and Manal sorts them based on their material. They then sell the sorted materials to the appropriate companies for recycling. 

Manal has applied for this loan to build a small storage unit for the collected scraps and to buy a small truck to help them in collecting the scraps in the future. 

Because Manal is a conservative person, her husband Maher has agreed appear in the picture in her place.

loans.use: to build a small storage unit and to buy a truck

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a married woman with one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past five years, she has operated a beauty salon business. Neighbors and passersby are her potential customers. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of owning a well- established cosmetics shop in the future.

With the KSHS 40,000, she wants to purchase cosmetics, food oil, weaves and hairpieces. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics, food oil, weaves and hairpieces.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more livestock

loans.name: Hong

texts.en: Mrs. Hong is a local rice farmer who lives in Prey Chor district.  She and her husband have done this job since 1998. They are blessed with eight kids, seven of them are single, and one is married and lives independently. She has some income from her two children who are employed in a restaurant in Phnom Penh City of Cambodia. Through help from their kids, Mrs. Hong’s house is getting older and older and she really wishes to rebuild it again, but she has still not enough money to do so. That is why Mrs. Hong would like to borrow some fund from Kiva loan to purchase columns in order to start building a new house. From this, Mrs. Hong and her family can live in the new house which is more safe than before. For her expectations in the future, Mrs. Hong wishes to send all their children to study at excellent schools.

loans.use: to purchase columns for building a new house.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a 45-year-old woman, who is married and has one son and two daughters. Her husband is an employee in a factory, and she owns a shop selling clothes in a lively commercial area and she wants to purchase seasonal clothes as the customer demand is getting higher. 

Mariam's husband doesn't have enough cash money to pay, so Mariam took out a loan of amount $2,000 from FATEN which can be repaid on an easy monthly basis.

Mariam's husband Mahmoud is photographed here as she is a conservative woman.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal clothes.

loans.name: Mwinyi

texts.en:
Mwinyi is a married man with three children, all of whom of whom attend school. He owns a house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, he has operated a retail shop business, selling to his neighbors and passersby. Mwinyi faces the major challenge of the high cost of transporting goods from town to his place of operation. He dreams of expanding to a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KSHS 80,000, he wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, cooking fat oil and sugar. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, cooking fat oil and sugar.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to restock his business by buying more apparel.

loans.name: Sulaika's Group

texts.en:
Sulaika, 49, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Karabalta, a small town near Bishkek (the capital of Kyrgyzstan). Together with her husband, she has raised two sons. About 20 years ago, Sulaika got cattle as an inheritance from her parents. Since that moment, she has been breeding cattle and reselling it after fattening. She also sells dairy products to make additional money. In this way, she earns 9000 soms per month. Sulaika applied for the loan because she needs additional financial funds to purchase more cattle. She hopes it will help her to increase the volume of dairy products. In the future, she wants to expand a shed where she keeps cattle. With the profits gained from the trade, Sulaika wishes to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchae cattle

loans.name: Kheang

texts.en:
Kheang, 49, and her husband, 50, have been farming since 1980. Both of them have skill and experience in the farming business. They have been married a long time and have four children. 

Her family is living in happiness because Kheang and her husband are able to gain enough cash each day, and two of their children are working in Phnom Penh for a suitable salary that they give to their parents every month. 

To raise the living standard of the family, Kheang wishes to ask $700 to purchase pigs to raise.

loans.use: to purchase pigs to raise.

loans.name: Kadiel Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kadiel est créé à l'ouverture du BV de Soucoupapaye. les 15  des membres qui composent ce groupe sont unis par des liens d'amitié. L'activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Mariama qui est à droite de la photo avec un sac rouge, est responsable du groupe. Elle est une veuve âgée de 63 ans, avec 04 enfants et 03 nièces à sa charge.

Elle s'active dans le petit commerce, mais elle cultive souvent les produits locaux qu'elle vend. elle est très expérimentée dans le secteur des légumes.

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer sa capacité de production et de faire plus de profits.

Les bénéfice sont destinés à améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille et accroitre son épargne.
texts.en:
Le groupe Kadiel est créé à l'ouverture du BV de Soucoupapaye. les 15  des membres qui composent ce groupe sont unis par des liens d'amitié. L'activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Mariama qui est à droite de la photo avec un sac rouge, est responsable du groupe. Elle est une veuve âgée de 63 ans, avec 04 enfants et 03 nièces à sa charge.

Elle s'active dans le petit commerce, mais elle cultive souvent les produits locaux qu'elle vend. elle est très expérimentée dans le secteur des légumes.

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer sa capacité de production et de faire plus de profits.

Les bénéfice sont destinés à améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille et accroitre son épargne.

loans.use: cultiver de la Patate Douce pour vendre

loans.name: Diamooral Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe diamooral existe depuis l'ouverture du Banc Villageois et les 10 membres qui le composent habitent le même secteur dans le quartier. Leur activité principale est le commerce.

Mme Nafissatou qui est à droite avec la main levée est la responsable du groupe. Elle est mariée et mère de deux enfants qui sont à la charge de son époux. 

Elle s'active dans le commerce de produits divers depuis plus de 5 ans. Elle s'approvisionne dans les marchés hebdomadaires de sa localité et va vendre à Dakar.

Ce prêt lui permet d'acheter plusieurs quantités et augmenter ainsi son revenu.Avec les bénéfices, elle compte appuyer son mari et accroitre son épargne.
texts.en:
Le groupe diamooral existe depuis l'ouverture du Banc Villageois et les 10 membres qui le composent habitent le même secteur dans le quartier. Leur activité principale est le commerce.

Mme Nafissatou qui est à droite avec la main levée est la responsable du groupe. Elle est mariée et mère de deux enfants qui sont à la charge de son époux. 

Elle s'active dans le commerce de produits divers depuis plus de 5 ans. Elle s'approvisionne dans les marchés hebdomadaires de sa localité et va vendre à Dakar.

Ce prêt lui permet d'acheter plusieurs quantités et augmenter ainsi son revenu.Avec les bénéfices, elle compte appuyer son mari et accroitre son épargne.

loans.use: acheter des balais, du citron, du miel et de l'huile de palme

loans.name: Walo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Walo est créé le 9 juillet 2011 jour de l'inauguration du Banc Villageois, il est composé de vingt cinq femmes issues du même quartier, elles sont sœurs, cousines et amies; elles s'activent dans le commerce, couture, coiffure et teinture.


Racky est âgée de 53 ans, elle est mariée et mène un commerce de produits divers, elle a une bonne expérience, elle fait aussi de l'aviculture. Sur la photo elle est debout à droite habillée en boubou vert et couverte d'un châle rougeâtre.

Elle s'approvisionne en( produits cosmétiques,chaussures, habits....) dans les villes voisines, dans la capitale et revend au marché central de sa ville ou elle posséde une boutique.

 Son prêt lui permettra de renforcer la quantité de la marchandise pour espérer ainsi gagner plus de revenus.


Elle souhaite ouvrir plus tard un compte dans les banques classiques mais également participer aux charges familiales et subvenir à ses besoins personnels.
texts.en:

Racky est âgée de 53 ans, elle est mariée et mène un commerce de produits divers, elle a une bonne expérience, elle fait aussi de l'aviculture. Sur la photo elle est debout à droite habillée en boubou vert et couverte d'un châle rougeâtre.

Elle s'approvisionne en( produits cosmétiques,chaussures, habits....) dans les villes voisines, dans la capitale et revend au marché central de sa ville ou elle posséde une boutique.

 Son prêt lui permettra de renforcer la quantité de la marchandise pour espérer ainsi gagner plus de revenus.


Elle souhaite ouvrir plus tard un compte dans les banques classiques mais également participer aux charges familiales et subvenir à ses besoins personnels.

loans.use: Acheter  des produits cosmétiques à revendre.

loans.name: Jappo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Jappo est créé le 9 juillet 2011 jour de l'inauguration du Banc Villageois, il est constitué de 25 femmes qui sont sœurs, amies, cousines, voisines qui habitent le même quartier et font de la couture, coiffure, teinture et le petit commerce.


Alimatou la responsable est âgée de 34 ans, elle est célibataire sans enfant et mène un commerce de produits cosmétiques et diverses marchandises, elle capitalise plus de 5 ans d'expérience; elle est debout sur la photo tout à fait à droite habillée en rouge.

Elle achéte ses marchandises ( produits cosmétiques, habits, chaussures, et tout article qui peut lui rapporter des bénéfices)dans les villes voisines et la capitale et revend au marché central de sa ville où elle posséde une boutique.


Elle envisage avec son prêt renforcer son activité en achetant plus de marchandises afin de gagner beaucoup de revenus.

Elle souhaite avec ses bénéfices se prendre totalement en charge.
texts.en:
Le groupe de solidarité Jappo est créé le 9 juillet 2011 jour de l'inauguration du Banc Villageois, il est constitué de 25 femmes qui sont sœurs, amies, cousines, voisines qui habitent le même quartier et font de la couture, coiffure, teinture et le petit commerce.


Alimatou la responsable est âgée de 34 ans, elle est célibataire sans enfant et mène un commerce de produits cosmétiques et diverses marchandises, elle capitalise plus de 5 ans d'expérience; elle est debout sur la photo tout à fait à droite habillée en rouge.

Elle achéte ses marchandises ( produits cosmétiques, habits, chaussures, et tout article qui peut lui rapporter des bénéfices)dans les villes voisines et la capitale et revend au marché central de sa ville où elle posséde une boutique.


Elle envisage avec son prêt renforcer son activité en achetant plus de marchandises afin de gagner beaucoup de revenus.

Elle souhaite avec ses bénéfices se prendre totalement en charge.

loans.use: Acheter des produits cosmétiques et  articles divers destinés à la vente.

loans.name: Wakeur Mousbah Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Wakeur Mousbah est créé le jour de l'inauguration du Banc Villageois le 7 juillet 2011, il est constitué de vingt trois femmes qui sont sœurs, amies , cousines, voisines et qui partagent les mêmes convictions religieuses; elles sont toutes des commerçantes.


Madame Aïchétou la responsable est âgée de 55 ans, mariée, mère de quatre enfants dont un garçon, elle a sa nièce en charge; elle mène une activité de commerce et fait parallèlement de l'embouche bovine, ovine et de la tannerie, elle a une bonne expérience de 7 ans. Sur la photo elle est debout à droite habillée en sari blanc orange.




Elle achéte ses produits, moutons et vaches dans un pays limitrophe et dans sa localité et revend dans son village.

Elle envisage avec son prêt acheter des parfums, draps, habits, chaussures....pour répondre aux besoins de la clientèle et ainsi gagner plus de revenus.



Elle souhaite avec ses bénéfices économiser pour ouvrir une cantine.
texts.en:
Le groupe de solidarité Wakeur Mousbah est créé le jour de l'inauguration du Banc Villageois le 7 juillet 2011, il est constitué de vingt trois femmes qui sont sœurs, amies , cousines, voisines et qui partagent les mêmes convictions religieuses; elles sont toutes des commerçantes.


Madame Aïchétou la responsable est âgée de 55 ans, mariée, mère de quatre enfants dont un garçon, elle a sa nièce en charge; elle mène une activité de commerce et fait parallèlement de l'embouche bovine, ovine et de la tannerie, elle a une bonne expérience de 7 ans. Sur la photo elle est de bout à droite habillée en sari blanc orange.




Elle achéte ses produits, moutons et vaches dans un pays limitrophe et dans sa localité et revend dans son village.

Elle envisage avec son prêt acheter des parfums, draps, habits, chaussures....pour répondre aux besoins de la clientèle et ainsi gagner plus de revenus.



Elle souhaite avec se bénéfices économiser pour ouvrir une cantine.

loans.use: Acheter des marchandises diverses destinées à la vente.

loans.name: Wakeur  Mareme Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité créé le jour de l'inauguration du Banc Villageois le 7 juillet 2011 est baptisé Wakeur Marème, il est composé de vingt cinq femmes qui habitent la même localité et sont parentes, amies et voisines; elles s'activent dans l'élevage,la tannerie, la confection de nattes et le commerce. 


La responsable Marème âgée de 26 ans est célibataire sans enfant mais a sa nièce en charge,elle mène une activité de petit commerce de produits divers et fait parallèlement de l'embouche ovine et bovine. Elle est tout à fait à droite habillée en sari noir avec des fleurs jaune rouge .


Elle achéte ses parfums, chaussures,habits, denrées alimentaires..... dans la capitale et les pays limitrophes et vend dans son village; elle capitalise une bonne expérience de 9 ans.

Son prêt lui servira à acheter des moutons pour l'embouche et des marchandises pour renforcer son commerce afin de gagner plus de revenus.

Elle souhaite avoir une autonomie financière et pouvoir acheter une parcelle de terrain pour y construire un magasin.
texts.en:

La responsable Marème âgée de 26 ans est célibataire sans enfant mais a sa nièce en charge,elle mène une activité de petit commerce de produits divers et fait parallèlement de l'embouche ovine et bovine. Elle est tout à fait à droite habillée en sari noir avec des fleurs jaune rouge .

Son prêt lui servira à acheter des moutons pour l'embouche et des marchandises pour renforcer son commerce afin de gagner plus de revenus.

Elle souhaite avoir une autonomie financière et pouvoir acheter une parcelle de terrain pour y construire un magasin.

loans.use: Faire du commerce et de l'embouche ovine.

loans.name: Fifonsi Group

texts.fr: FIFONSI est un groupement constitué de onze personnes et dont la présidente (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) se nomme Laure Sèblo. Les membres du groupe vivent dans le même quartier au Bénin. Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement, ce groupe FIFONSI sollicite pour la première fois un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Laure Sèblo est âgée de 47 ans et vit au Bénin. Laure Sèblo est une veuve ayant cinq enfants à sa charge, dont deux représentent ses propres enfants. Parmi les enfants, certains sont scolarisés. Laure Sèblo assure seule les diverses charges des enfants. Laure Sèblo n'a pas été à l'école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Laure Sèblo mène comme activité, la vente de chaussures dans une ville du Bénin. Laure Sèblo est également une restauratrice qui vend du riz accompagné de sauce, des pâtes alimentaires, etc. Laure Sèblo s'approvisionne au Bénin. Laure Sèblo exerce cette activité depuis une douzaine d'année, ce qui lui permet d’assurer les diverses charges de sa famille. Ce premier prêt permettra certainement à Laure Sèblo et aux autres membres du groupement FIFONSI de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d'augmenter leur chiffre d'affaire et leur clientèle. Plus tard,Laure Sèblo ambitionne acquérir une parcelle et construire une maison.
texts.en:
FIFONSI is a group made up of 11 persons whose leader (the woman who is raising her hand in the photo) is named Laure Sèblo. The members of the group live in the same neighborhood in Bénin. For the first time, in order to grow their working capital, this FIFONSI group is requesting a loan from ALIDé.

 Laure Sèblo, 47, lives in Bénin. She is a widow raising five children, two of whom are her biological children. Some of these children are enrolled in school. Laure Sèblo supports the children all by herself. 

 Laure Sèblo did not attend school. To earn a living, she sells shoes in a town in Bénin. She also sells cooked rice with sauce, pasta, etc. She buys her supplies in Bénin. She has been working at this businss for a dozen years, and it allows her to cover her family's daily expenses. This first loan will surely permit  Laure Sèblo and the other members of the FIFONSI group to raise the level of their businesses and grow their turnover and their clientele. 

Later on, Laure Sèblo would like to acquire a parcel of land and build a house.

loans.use: to buy 10 dozen pairs of shoes and one sack of rice.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam is a focused and calm 34-year-old business lady. She is married and blessed with two school-going children aged 8 and 4 years old. Since the year 2005, she has been operating a beauty salon to make ends meet. Previously, she used to run a butchery. She wants in the next five years to expand her business and accumulate enough capital to make her dream of opening up a salon training school a reality.

She is requesting a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy cosmetics to use in her salon. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, she is now financially literate.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics to use in her salon

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 53 years old, single and blessed with children. She owns a grocery store. She has been in this business for the last two years and gets an income of KES 5,000 per month.

She is applying for her first loan of KES 5,000 from KADET LTD, which she plans to use to expand her business by buying more potatoes, cabbage, carrots, and onions. She plans to use the anticipated profit to buy more goods to expand the business.

She hopes to have a successful business and help her children.

loans.use: To buy more potatoes, cabbage, carrots, and onions

loans.name: Tour Grace Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 28-year-old Mercy from Gweru. She is married with one child, age 9 years, who attends school. She also cares for one dependent. 

Mercy runs a retail butchery selling meat and small groceries. The business has been in operation for two years. She says the main challenge she faces is power shortages.

Mercy is applying for a loan of $400 to buy cattle and chicken for her butchery. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to send her child to a good school.
								
In the future Mercy plans to open a bigger market and start a cattle fattening project.

loans.use: To buy cattle and chicken for her butchery.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth, a 27-year-old married mother of two children, has been selling vegetables to earn a living for four years now.  She also does poultry farming to earn additional income for her family.  Since joining Faulu Kenya, Ruth has improved her business and hence her living standards. Hoping to expand her enterprise in the future, she has requested a loan of 25,000 Kenyan shillings to buy sweet potatoes, carrots and tomatoes to sell.

loans.use: to buy sweet potatoes, carrots and tomatoes.

loans.name: Jeniffer

texts.en:
Jeniffer, a married woman with one child who attends school, owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, Jeniffer has operated a retail shop, selling household consumables to her neighbours and passersby. She faces the major business challenge of high transportation costs, and her major dream is to expand into a wholesale shop in the future.

Having joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business, Jeniffer is requesting a loan of Kshs 30,000 to purchase six bundles of maize flour, three sacks of beans, cooking oil and sweets.

loans.use: to purchase six bundles of maize flour, three sacks of beans, cooking oil and sweets.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes and shoes for sale.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam lives in Kampong Chhnang province.  She is married and has seven children.   Two are single and five are married.  

To earn a living, Mrs. Sam sells rice soup in the busy market.  Her husband, who is a pig breeder, supports the family as well by raising pigs for slaughter.  The family typically earns about $3.5 per day.  Mrs. Sam would like to take out a loan to help her husband purchase two sows to raise and sell for slaughter.  She will use the remainder of the loan to mend her broken house.  

Mrs. Sam’s family currently lives in a thatched house, but if she and her husband can increase their income, they hope to build a wooden house that will be more protected from flooding.

loans.use: to purchase two sows and repair her broken house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a blow dryer

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane, age 41, earns a living through dairy farming. She has been farming for over 10 years. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has improved her business and has become more financially stable. She and her husband have four children, all enrolled in school.

Jane hopes to succeed in her business in the future. She has requested a loan in the amount of 40,000 Kenyan Shillings in order to buy a dairy cow.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine, age 33, earns a living by selling second-hand clothes. She has been operating her business for almost two years and she employs one person to assist her. She and her husband have two children, both enrolled in school. 
 
Catherine hopes to buy a piece of land in the future. She has requested a loan in the amount of 30,000 Kenyan shillings to buy clothes, bed sheets, and curtains to offer for sale.

loans.use: to buy clothes, bed sheets, and curtains to offer for sale

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Mme Mariam est veuve et mère de 06 enfants. Le plus âgé a 31ans et le moins âgé a 19ans.03 vont a l’école et elle a 05 personnes a sa charge.

Elle vend du dolo depuis 10ans. Mme s’approvisionne dans les marchés des villages environnants. Ses clients sont ses voisins, amis et tous ceux qui fréquentent le marché ou elle vend.

Elle veut s’acheter 10 sacs de mil rouge et une demi-camionnette de bois.

Mme économise ses bénéfices pour entretenir ses enfants et construire sa maison. Elle ambitionne ouvrir plusieurs lieu de vente du dolo, vendre aussi du bois par camionnette et s’occuper de la scolarisation de ses enfants.
texts.en: Ms. Mariam is a widow and the mother of six children. The eldest is 31 years old, and the youngest is 19. Three of them go to school. Mariam has five persons to support. She has been selling dolo (a kind of beer) for ten years. She gets her supplies from the markets of surrounding villages. Her customers are her neighbors, friends, and anyone who comes to the market where she sells. She wants to buy 10 sacks of red millet and a half truckload of wood. Mariam is saving her profits to care for her children and to build a house. Her ambition is to open several dolo outlets and also to sell truckloads of wood and to cover the cost of schooling for her children.

loans.use: to buy 10 sacks of red millet and a half truckload of wood

loans.name: Angeline

texts.en:
Angeline has operated a cosmetic shop business for the past six years, selling at the market to her neighbors and passers-by. She also does farming which provides a secondary source of income. Angeline faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of becoming a wholesale distributor of cosmetics in the future. 

Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. She and her husband have one school-aged child and live a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

With the Kshs 15,000 loan she has requested, Angeline wants to purchase bundles of body lotions and hair products. She decided to join Yehu in order to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of body lotions and hair products to offer for sale

loans.name: Nurgazy's Group

texts.en:
Nurgazy, age 20, is a member of this loan group. He is a resident of Karabalta, a small town near Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan. Nurgazy lives together with his parents, both of whom are pensioners. In order to earn money to meet their daily needs, the family breeds cattle and sells dairy products. Nurgazy has applied for the loan because he needs some additional financial funds in order to install a fence at the family home. In the future, he wants to have a successful business so as to be able to support his parents financially.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line:
– People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), 
– Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and 
– Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 
MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in central Asia, please join our Lending Team "Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance" at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to install a fence at his home

loans.name: Antony

texts.en:
Antony, age 27 and unmarried, owns a motorcycle whereby he operates a bodaboda business in Tala town. He has been engaged in this business for the last two years and earns an income of KES.20,000 per month.

Antony is applying for his first loan of KES 20,000 from KADET Ltd., with which he plans to buy spare parts for the motorcycle. He plans to use the extra profit expected from this loan in order eventually to buy another motorcycle. He hopes to own a matatu.

loans.use: to buy spare motorcycle parts to repair his vehicle

loans.name: Ma.fe

texts.en:
This is Ma.Fe, 38, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Romulo, a welder. She has three children: two are in high school and one is in elementary school. With her husband and children, she manages their household and operates the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Ma.Fe operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She also earns income by selling personal products through direct selling. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.
